results.title: From Melville to Melbourne
results.creator_credit: Tristan Mungatopi, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI

results.title: To my dearest beloved one - Shewitey Mearey
results.brief_description: A personal account created by a participant in the ACMI Digital Storytelling Workshop “Journeys with Breast Cancer” Created in association with Breast Cancer Network Australia. “I said to the doctor, I don’t care if I die tomorrow but I don’t want to leave my daughter alone. He said to me that first I had to live before I could have another child.”
results.title_for_label: To my dearest beloved one - Shewitey Mearey
results.description: A personal account created by a participant in the ACMI Digital Storytelling Workshop “Journeys with Breast Cancer” Created in association with Breast Cancer Network Australia. “I said to the doctor, I don’t care if I die tomorrow but I don’t want to leave my daughter alone. results.title: The Genie from down under: good cop, bad genie
results.creator_credit: Australian Children's Television Foundation, ABC-TV (Australia), British Broadcasting Corporation, Patricia Edgar, Phil Jones and Brendan Maher
results.brief_description: Penelope is desperate to win the Cross Country and she does - without any help from the genies. Penelope wishes that Conrad could see her success. He does - but not quite how Penelope would have liked.

results.title: The Genie from down under: customs
results.creator_credit: Australian Children's Television Foundation, ABC-TV (Australia), British Broadcasting Corporation, Patricia Edgar, Phil Jones and Jeremy Swan
results.brief_description: Penelope, Lady Diana and Miss Mossop are arrested by a Customs Officer when they return to England with 20 million pounds provided by the genies. That exact amount has just gone missing from the Royal Mint.

results.title: The Genie from down under: larceny
results.creator_credit: Australian Children's Television Foundation, ABC-TV (Australia), British Broadcasting Corporation, Patricia Edgar, Phil Jones and Brendan Maher
results.brief_description: Bruce helps Otto and Conrad get the opal because he thinks they will help him return to Australia. Instead, the von Meisters sell it for 25,000 pounds. It’s now up to the genies to sort the mess out.

results.title: The Genie from down under: wishing and hoping
results.creator_credit: Australian Children's Television Foundation, ABC-TV (Australia), British Broadcasting Corporation, Patricia Edgar, Phil Jones and Esben Storm
results.brief_description: When upper class English girl Penelope Townes finds a magic opal which contains two Australian genies, Bruce and his son Baz, she thinks all her problems are over, and that she can have anything she wants. Bruce, however, has other ideas.

results.title: The Genie from down under: it's my opal and I'll cry if I want to
results.creator_credit: Australian Children's Television Foundation, ABC-TV (Australia), British Broadcasting Corporation, Patricia Edgar, Phil Jones and Jeremy Swan
results.brief_description: Tour operator, Otto von Meister, and his nephew, Conrad, arrive at Townes Downs with a load of tourists. When he learns about the opal Otto recalls that it belonged to their family years before and he and Conrad are desperate to get it back.
results.title_for_label: The Genie from down under: it’s my opal and I’ll cry if I want to

results.title: The Genie from down under: where it's at
results.creator_credit: Australian Children's Television Foundation, ABC-TV (Australia), British Broadcasting Corporation, Patricia Edgar, Phil Jones and Esben Storm
results.brief_description: Bruce wants to become human but to do this he must take the opal to the cave where it was mined over a hundred years before. He sets out to trick Penelope into visiting the cave.

results.title: The Memory of Water (part 1)
results.credit_line: Video excerpt and still images on this page are provided courtesy of the artist.
results.brief_description:
The ‘Memory of Water (part 1)’ explores Carl Jung’s notion of the ‘collective unconscious’, examining consciousness in the form of memory or perceived experience and the power of the gaze as that which mediates external phenomena. Sadia’s video explores the relationship between the drop and the ocean in terms of human experience. While the camera is trained in close up on their eyes, a series of people answer the question, “What is your most significant memory?”

The words and the eyes are played out of sync, so that one person’s voice speaks under another’s gaze. This simple device releases the memories from individual ownership, and the work becomes a gesture towards transcendence. Informed by the Jungian notion of the collective unconscious, The Memory of Water examines the gaze as a bridge between inner and outer worlds.

results.title: Jaara Nyilamum
results.creator_credit: Lou Bennett AM and Romaine Moreton
results.credit_line:
Dr Romaine Moreton (Goenpul Yagerabul Minjungbal Bundjalung) and Dr Lou Bennett AM (Dja Dja Wurrung, Yorta Yorta)

Single-channel video, 7.39 mins

Filmed and edited by Dr Romaine Moreton

Co-directed by Dr Romaine Moreton and Dr Lou Bennett AM

Jaara Nyilamum (song composition) Performed by Dr Lou Bennett AM and the Australian String Quartet

Composed by Dr Lou Bennett AM

Arranged by Iain Grandage

Produced by Stephen Snelleman

Engineered by Russell Thomson

ACMI Collection
results.brief_description:
“The making of “Jaara Nyilamum” (2021) evoked a stillness that restored us to full sensual immersion within Country, and from this place of rooted calmness, Country reaffirmed our Law is real. “Jaara Nyilamum” became most profound when we realised this was more than a film about ceremony, but was in fact, ceremony itself. Our challenge was to create a production model that aligned with our beliefs and centralised our Law, pushed back against monochronic time and engaged with the deep cycles of place, where we embraced Belonging as a process of constant renewal and Rematration.” – Dr Lou Bennett AM and Dr Romaine Moreton

Dr Lou Bennett is a performer, songwriter, musical and artistic director, composer, actor, soundscape designer and academic. Lou’s research project ‘Sovereign Language Rematriation Through Song Pedagogy’ focusses on the importance and relevance of Indigenous language retrieval, reclamation, and regeneration through the medium of the arts to enhance community health and wellbeing.

Dr Romaine Moreton is an artist, writer, performer, filmmaker, and her proposes an Indigenous philosophy of storytelling and embodied knowledge, with her work constantly drawing our attention back to the importance of the breath in Indigenous cultural practices.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Dr Romaine Moreton (Goenpul Yagerabul Minjungbal Bundjalung), Dr Lou Bennett AM (Dja Dja Wurrung, Yorta Yorta)
